fields.description:
Steps:
1. Login to JIRA and create a applinks with OAuth access type.
2. Configure the Bamboo plugin to JIRA project.
3. Now login to bamboo and in build summary page, there is message next to JIRA issue key "Login and Authenticate to see more". Click it, it ask user to login to JIRA and then normal OAuth dance. Once finish user expect to be back to Bamboo build summary page.

Result:
1. It ask user to login to bamboo again. As I never logout of bamboo, user should be back to build summary page.
fields.summary: Bamboo ask user to login again when user authenticate for a JIRA server using oAuth.

fields.description: A UI Tests build (https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/UPM-UITESTS-130) failed.  I re-ran the failed jobs of that build a few times to try to shake out any non-deterministic tests.  I noticed this morning that the build had a duration of 92 minutes, much higher than the durations of the adjacent builds (~10 minutes).  Additionally, if I add up the durations of the jobs in the build (most of which ran in parallel), the duration was well less than 92 minutes.
fields.summary: Build duration is misleading if failed jobs are re-run

fields.description:
It seems when using an Bamboo ant builder edits the system Path variable to prefix it with the JDK bin directory. When it does this it also changes the name of the variable to be all upper case. When I use the exec task from ant I end up with two variables 'Path' and 'PATH' which are different. 

When I use the ant exec task to run the set command from the command shell like so:

{code}
<exec executable="cmd" failonerror="true">
    <arg value="/c"/>
    <arg value="set"/>
</exec>
{code}

In the bamboo log I can see that there are duplicate paths:

{code}
24-Aug-2011 11:00:32 	     [exec] Path=C:\Program Files (x86)\CollabNet\Subversion Client;C:\cygwin\bin;C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_26\bin;C:\apache-ant-1.7.1\bin;C:\apache-maven-3.0.3\bin;C:\Python26;C:\Python26\Scripts;C:\Windows\system32;C:\Windows;C:\Windows\System32\Wbem;C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\;C:\Program Files\TortoiseSVN\bin;C:\Program Files\TortoiseGit\bin
24-Aug-2011 11:00:32 	     [exec] PATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_26\bin;C:\Program Files (x86)\CollabNet\Subversion Client;C:\cygwin\bin;C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_26\bin;C:\apache-ant-1.7.1\bin;C:\apache-maven-3.0.3\bin;C:\Python26;C:\Python26\Scripts;C:\Windows\system32;C:\Windows;C:\Windows\System32\Wbem;C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\;C:\Program Files\TortoiseSVN\bin;C:\Program Files\TortoiseGit\bin
{code}

The first is the default system path, and the second is the edited version added by bamboo.

I think this issue is probably related to     

BAM-1660 - Duplicate Path variable(s) added by Bamboo when executing Build on windows
fields.summary: Bamboo does not preserve case of Path environment variable

fields.description:
* Maybe I want to deploy to a different server than my plan dictates.  I can't do this because prior builds will have the plan level variables set and you can't change the variables on the fly to take effect
* Maybe I want to change my maven version on my release tag on my manual stage (my real selfish request here)
* Maybe I want to call the release tag something else and I normally have this set in the plan variables (also selfish)

We are stuck right now on the plan level if a build has run and we want to go back and run a manual stage that we are stuck with the variables of that past run.  A parameterised manual stage FTW!  :)

[~bmccoy] also thought this was a good idea  :)
fields.summary: Manual stages to be able to run parameterized variables

fields.description:
We have multi modules project structure like :

{code}
ParentPom
|-- pom.xml (Modules : SampleProjectEAR,SampleProjectWeb,SampleProjectCommons)
SampleProjectEAR
|-- pom.xml (Parent : ParentPom pom.xml)
SampleProjectWeb
|-- pom.xml (Parent : ParentPom pom.xml)
SampleProjectCommons
|-- pom.xml (Parent : ParentPom pom.xml)
{code}

In maven, we have a *release plan* with a *release task* (a *Maven 3.x Configuration* task) with fields :
goal = release:clean release:prepare release:perform -B -U
*Override Project File = ParentPom/pom.xml*

When running this plan, we've got the following error :
{code}
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Building SampleProject 2.3.15-SNAPSHOT
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] 
[INFO] --- maven-release-plugin:2.2.1:perform (default-cli) @ SampleProject ---
[INFO] Checking out the project to perform the release ...
[INFO] Performing a LOCAL checkout from scm:git:file:///app/DINB/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/WTUT-RELEASE-JOB1/ParentPom
[INFO] Executing: /bin/sh -c cd /app/DINB/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/WTUT-RELEASE-JOB1/ParentPom/target && git clone file:///app/DINB/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/WTUT-RELEASE-JOB1/ParentPom /app/DINB/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/WTUT-RELEASE-JOB1/ParentPom/target/checkout
[INFO] Working directory: /app/DINB/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/WTUT-RELEASE-JOB1/ParentPom/target
[ERROR] The git-clone command failed.
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Reactor Summary:
[INFO] 
[INFO] SampleProject .................................... FAILURE [1.291s]
[INFO] SampleProjectCommons ............................. SKIPPED
[INFO] SampleProjectWeb ................................. SKIPPED
[INFO] SampleProjectEAR ................................. SKIPPED
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] BUILD FAILURE
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Total time: 1.833s
[INFO] Finished at: Fri Aug 12 11:55:47 UTC 2011
[INFO] Final Memory: 5M/146M
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-release-plugin:2.2.1:perform (default-cli) on project SampleProject: Unable to checkout from SCM
[ERROR] Provider message:
[ERROR] The git-clone command failed.
[ERROR] Command output:
[ERROR] fatal: '/app/DINB/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/WTUT-RELEASE-JOB1/ParentPom' does not appear to be a git repository
[ERROR] fatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly
[ERROR] -> [Help 1]
[ERROR] 
{code}

In fact, it's true ! */app/DINB/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/WTUT-RELEASE-JOB1/ParentPom* is not a git repository but */app/DINB/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/WTUT-RELEASE-JOB1* is !

We have to find the way to tell BAMBOO to use root directory as root GIT repository...

Julien
fields.summary: Could not release project due to GIT clone error when working in sub-directory

fields.description:
http://tardigrade.sydney.atlassian.com:8085/bamboo/browse/BAM-EXT-4049

on bamboo-hg repository,
lastVcsRevisionKey = 1c969a8270b7b6b70ff7f855a31fde22d3abae0c (Marcin Gardias code change)
currentRevisionKey = 06998bc525a291de042309b8972e5d743d491d8b (Krystian's merge)

between those two revisions Bamboo has found 106 code changes. Due to hard limit (100 changeset parsed for the build, no more) the Mercurial Repository falsely filters out the not-relevant changesets to current branch:
bq. The Mercurial Plugin might incorrectly report the changesets triggering the build *if* there was more than 100 (HgRepository.CHANGESET_LIMIT) changes between the last build. The Mercurial Plugin will just have not enough information to traverse the changeset graph properly and will in defense report all changesets between, even those non-related to the built branch.
Code responsible is near here: [HgCommandProcessor.filterOutUnreachableChangesets|https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/browse/bamboo-hg/components/bamboo-plugins/bamboo-plugin-mercurial/src/main/java/com/atlassian/bamboo/plugins/hg/HgCommandProcessor.java?r=d8b981d129d0#to384]

I'm raising this issue so we can have a look at in in better detail.
fields.summary: Mercurial Repository should correctly filter changesets since last build (even if there was more than 100 changesets)

fields.summary: Can't add build plan dependencies (possibly after deleting unrelated projects)

fields.description: There has been come confusion on Answers and support on what the exact behaviour is. We need to document this and link to the docs from the Task UI
fields.summary: Document how arguments are quoted for all platforms and link to Task UI

fields.description: I would like to be able to configure concurrency settings for a plan so that the a given stage can not run concurrently, but different stages can.  The use case is our current confluence deployment build, https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-CDOG/.  This build ensures the same artifact is deployed to CDOG then to extranet staging then to EAC.  Obviously it would be a very bad thing for two deployments to run at the same time on the same machine, but it is sometimes frustrating to have to wait for a time when CDOG is not continuously deploying to be able to upgrade EAC.
fields.summary: Stage level concurrency settings

fields.description: It would be handy to show the revision a plan ran against when viewing the history of a plan. I was trying to see if a green func test build also had a corresponding green selenium test build but I had to just look at the time stamp in each one and then open each plan which ran around that time to see the revision it was built off.
fields.summary: Show the revision on the history tab of a plan

fields.description: Add a link to the Task UI pointing to the doc page requested at BAM-9502
fields.summary: Link tasks to the doc page that explains how arguments with space can be quoted
Document and make public how arguments with space can be quoted in Task fields

fields.description: When you switch between chain and job configuration, the tab is always reset to the first one. It seems that the cookie handling is OK, it just gets reset to 0 every time the page is changed, probably because page.properties["meta.tab"] is always set to the same value .
fields.summary: Tab in plan/chain configuration is no longer remembered

fields.description:
When the Spot Request expires, AWS sometimes reports it as cancelled, although an instance has been launched. According to the documentation, it should be either "Closed" or "Active".
We need a workaround for that, such instances will be dropped and will not connect to Bamboo.
fields.summary: AWS does not correctly report spot instance requests state if they expire

fields.description:
From BSP-5157.
The symptoms are uhm, not straightforward to interpret:
"sh: line 0: exec: java: not found"
fields.summary: Bamboo startup script will fail when GREP_OPTIONS=--color=always

fields.description: It's called "Manual" in the UI. We need to ensure that we use terms from the UI in the log and not from the code that users can't see.
fields.summary: Don't call it "finalising" task finalising in the audit log

fields.description:
This should be very straightforward now that [AO-156|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/AO-156] is resolved. I've verified that AO works essentially out of the box with Bamboo 3.2.

All that needs to be done is bundle the following two artifacts into Bamboo:

{noformat}
com.atlassian.activeobjects:activeobjects-plugin:0.16.1
com.atlassian.activeobjects:activeobjects-bamboo-spi:0.16.1
{noformat}

If the two bundles are enabled upon system startup then everything should work.
fields.summary: Bundle AO into Bamboo

fields.description: In trying to streamline my remote agents, having the matrix page either an interactive or sortable table would be quite useful.
fields.summary: Make the agent's matrix more usable, or exportable to a CSV/Excel

fields.description:
Bamboo looks for the java in path and ignores the JAVA_HOME. This has caused confusion for evaluators and often Bamboo fails to startup if the JAVA_HOME is set to point to a SUN JDK and java in the PATH points to openjdk on standard Linux distros. Additionally,

# JIRA/Confluence use JAVA_HOME as opposed to picking up java in user path.
# I had another customer who had multiple java executables in his PATH and we went back and forth for a week before solving this mystery.
fields.summary: Bamboo should use the java defined in JAVA_HOME

fields.description: So, it is not possible to define artifact location as ${bamboo.someVersion}
fields.summary: Artifacts don't use variable substitution

fields.description:
I am trying to create an artifact definition to consume the output of one of my other jobs. The path for the artifact looks something like this:

P'X5 Software/Output/awb_builder/P'X5 Documentation

Our company's product name is P'X5, which is why the apostrophe is in there. I could work around this bug by renaming everything in my documentation system (which produces this output), but that's a poor man's fix.l
fields.summary: Artifact definition does not allow the use of an apostrophe in the location path

fields.description:
When configuring Source Repository we can see {color:gray}_"Mercurial is currently set to use /usr/bin/hg as the Mercurial Executable on the Bamboo Server. To run a Mercurial build remotely please ensure that the Mercurial Executable capability is defined for the agents."_{color} when choosing Mercurial as Source Control.
However, we don't see that description when Creating New Plan. This is particularly annoying because that description can contain link to administration panel where customer can detect server capabilities (including Mercurial Capability which is needed to set up Mercurial plans)
fields.summary: Mercurial description should be also visible when creating new plan.

fields.description:
When User configure trusted application to communicate between JIRA and Bamboo. The feature release version will not work properly. The JIRA will not show the following in the UI 
!bamboojira.png|thumbnail!

This problem does not happen when using basic authentication in application link. As a workaround user can try with basic authentication.jira
fields.summary: Release feature in  JIRA  and Bamboo with trusted application not working properly

fields.description: Instead of comparing the bootstrap path for elastic bamboo we should compare against "/opt/bamboo-elastic-agent/lib"
fields.summary: Enable dynamic bootstrap for Elastic Bamboo

fields.description: I was just thinking that notification schemes would be cool. We have a lot of plans and if I want to apply the same notifications to all our plans I have to do it one plan at a time at the moment. It would be cool to be able to define a notification scheme and then select that scheme for a plan.
fields.summary: Notification schemes

fields.description:
Try to open url:
https://gdansk.bamboo2.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/result/TRANS-TST-161?expand=jiraIssues&auth=7P91L2nJT3

you'll get : 

<status>
<status-code>500</status-code>
</status>
fields.summary: 500 response after getting JIRA issues for Build

fields.description:
To reproduce, install a plugin containing at least one module annotated with {{@RequiresRestart}} (via UPM). You will get a message that the plugin will be installed next time the server is started and it does indeed. Now go to UPM and try to uninstall the plugin. A similar message will be displayed. Restart Bamboo go to UPM and the plugin is still running - it does not get uninstalled upon server restart. 

You can still uninstall the plugin by manually removing it from ${bamboo-home}/plugins.
fields.summary: Plugins v2 with modules annotated with @RequiresRestart do not get uninstalled via UPM
"Set Up Administrator User" page has double Finish button

fields.description: When creating a Job, bamboo doesn't seem to validate the 'Job Key' correctly. Typing in a lowercase 'a' and trying to submit returns the message "A Job key must consist of an uppercase letter followed by one or more uppercase alphanumeric characters." However, it will accept any sequence of lowercase letters longer than one character.
fields.summary: Incorrect validation of Job Key in the job creation dialogue.
Ability to enable and disable new bootstrap on elastic agents.

fields.description:
This would allow customers to identify/decide/understand if the upgrade would break features that are critical for their builds.

This is not a perfect solution, since it would not allow to track problems that were identified in old releases and that were not fixed yet. However, it should help to improve the understanding of what was already found in the release.
fields.summary: Add a JIRA Issues gadget to the Bamboo Upgrade notes so that customers can know what were the bugs/improvements already filed for the release

fields.description: As discussed https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-BAM-3297#c56405
fields.summary: Move Windows unquoting from ProcessServiceImpl to atlassian-process-utils

fields.description: As Darek proposed in https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-BAM-3338#c57569
fields.summary: Start using javax.annotation versions of @Nullable/@NotNull

fields.description: As discussed here: https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-BAM-3338#c57429
fields.summary: Create a builder for User entities and deprecate/remove multiple addUser/saveUser methods in BambooUserManager

fields.description:
Remove axis libs from Bamboo - we're not using SOAP anymore.
Anyway remember to add them explicitely in BRMP plugin (to keep it compatible).
fields.summary: Remove axis libs from Bamboo

fields.description:
Raised from BSP-5081.
It seems that when the agent encounters HTTP redirects (e.g. HTTP->HTTPS), apache commons logging is unable to load its configuration file.
I think it's best if we blindly upgrade commons logging to the latest version - it may solve the problem.
Forking AC-L to implement redirect support looks like an overkill - we can always ask the customer to define the base url correctly.
fields.summary: Remote agents do not work with HTTP redirects

fields.description:
The [Configuring Notifications for a Plan and its Jobs|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+Notifications+for+a+Plan+and+its+Jobs] document should be improved. It's not saying the customer needs to set up a mapping between the repository committer/author and the Bamboo user.

For committers to receive notification, the author must be mapped to the Bamboo user.
fields.summary: Improve plan and job notification document

fields.description: Option to disable the artifact storage feature in Bamboo
fields.summary: Disable artifact storage

fields.description:
I need to be able to create artifact definitions using plan variables, e.g. Name = ${bamboo.Artifact1Name}, location = ${bamboo.artifact1location}, copypattern = ${bamboo.copypattern}

We can use plan variables everywhere else - why not here?
fields.summary: as a user I want to be able to use variables in creating artifact definitions

fields.description:
details: [CR-BAM-3225|https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-BAM-3225#c57689]

I did brake a bit jira-bamboo-plugin - when you try to do a release from the JIRA you would have by default all stages checked. Good. However, if you deselect some stages and make some validation error (I don't remember how I simulated the validation errors - probably I'd plugged with debugger and thrown them when needed) you return to the same page with all stages checked again. You should have checked only those left checked.
fields.summary: jira-bamboo-plugin -> the unselected stages should stay unselected after validation failure

fields.description:
Our [docs state|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Labelling+a+Plan] that a user just needs to be logged in order to add a label to a plan.

Currently, the option is displayed in the Actions menu, but it does not work if the user does not have permission to edit the plan.

Adding a label to a Build Result is still working fine.

See screen shots attached.
fields.summary: Users can't add Labels to a Plan if they don't have permission to edit it or are not Admins

fields.description:
You have your plan being triggered by code changes and one job checking our source code and creating an artifact but ALL the other jobs dont have a repository set up.  Any notifications you get for those jobs say they are triggered by code changes but you don't see who made those changes or what the changes were.

Maybe if there is no repository configured we could add another section.  "Plan triggered by the following changes: X" or even just list the authors that were responsible with the trigger message maybe?
fields.summary: Job Emails should contain Plan's commit information when it has none of its own.

fields.description:
In Bamboo 3.2, in order to setup an OAuth consumer you need to first trust 2 applications, and then you'll able to add an OAuth consumer.

This document is out of date: 

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+OAuth+Consumers

It says on Step 3: _In the left-hand menu, under the title 'Gadgets', click the 'OAuth Consumers' link. The 'OAuth Administration' page will be displayed, showing a list of configured OAuth Consumers (if any exist)._

There is no such option under the Gadgets section, only "Available Gadgets", and that page has no OAuth links either.
fields.summary: Configuring OAuth Consumers document is out of date

fields.description:
See [https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/5327/how-do-you-use-the-bamboo-rest-api-to-add-a-comment-to-a-build-that-includes-a-jira-key-that-will-be-indexed-by-the-bamboo-jira-plugin] for the details. 

When adding comments via REST api Bamboo doesn't recognize the jira issues contained in the content of the comment.
fields.summary: "add comment" REST Api point doesn't find and save jira issue keys.

fields.description:
Recently I caught myself on clicking the summary's revisions - expecting I'd be redirected to the fisheye view for that particular revision (or something similar).

For example in the attached screenshot revision I'd like to be redirected either to:
* https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/changelog/bamboo-hg/?showid=6534de4477
or to:
* https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/changelog/bamboo-hg?cs=6534de4477c4a5b136dafe1d2b1db3a4f3a2c955
fields.summary: Make the revision visible in the build summary screens clickable.

fields.description:
When the capability is being added, the description says:
(Enter the )"Path of the NAnt executable eg C:\nant\bin\nant.exe"
The result is: Executable 'nant.exe' does not exist at path 'C:\Program Files\NAnt\bin\NAnt.exe\bin\nant.exe') 
We should probably have a look at all executables and see if they follow a common pattern.
fields.summary: Misleading configuration of NAnt executable

fields.description:
I've noticed that automatic build dependencies stopped working after somewhere along the way of upgrades from bamboo 2.6 (I must have missed relevant release notes entry). After a quick glance at the configuration panels I've figured out that I need to add a 'Maven Dependencies Processor' task to my build plan. Unfortunately the task fails, despite the fact that Maven 2.x task in the same job succeeds. Error message is

{code}
03-Aug-2011 11:34:48	Automatic Maven plan dependencies processing failed: Cannot find parent: org.objectledge:ledge-common for project: null:ledge-components:jar:null for project null:ledge-components:jar:null
{code} 

It appears that Maven Dependency Processor task has trouble resolving the parent project from a remote repository. Here's how my setup looks like.

{code:xml|title=ledege-components/pom.xml}
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
  xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0
                      http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
  <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
  <parent>
    <groupId>org.objectledge</groupId>
    <artifactId>ledge-common</artifactId>
    <relativePath>../ledge-common/pom.xml</relativePath>
    <version>1.0.11-SNAPSHOT</version>
  </parent>
  <artifactId>ledge-components</artifactId>
  <packaging>jar</packaging>
  <!-- ... -->
</project>
{code}

{code:xml|title=ledge-common/pom.xml}
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
  xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0
                      http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">

  <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
  <groupId>org.objectledge</groupId>
  <artifactId>ledge-common</artifactId>
  <packaging>pom</packaging>
  <version>1.0.11-SNAPSHOT</version>
  <!-- ... -->
  <repositories>
    <repository>
      <id>nexus</id>
      <name>Objectledge Nexus repository</name>
      <url>http://objectledge.org/nexus/content/groups/m2</url>      
      <releases>
        <enabled>true</enabled>
      </releases>
      <snapshots>
        <enabled>true</enabled>
        <updatePolicy>never</updatePolicy>
      </snapshots>
    </repository>
  </repositories>
  <pluginRepositories>
    <pluginRepository>
      <id>nexus</id>
      <name>Objectledge Nexus repository (plugins)</name>
      <url>http://objectledge.org/nexus/content/groups/m2</url>
      <releases>
        <enabled>true</enabled>
      </releases>
      <snapshots>
        <enabled>true</enabled>
        <updatePolicy>never</updatePolicy>
      </snapshots>
    </pluginRepository>
  </pluginRepositories>
  <distributionManagement>
    <repository>
      <id>nexus.objectledge.org</id>
      <name>ObjectLedge releases Nexus repository</name>
      <url>http://nexus.objectledge.org/nexus/content/repositories/m2releases</url>
    </repository>
    <snapshotRepository>
      <id>nexus.objectledge.org</id>
      <name>ObjectLedge snapshots Nexus repository</name>
      <url>http://nexus.objectledge.org/nexus/content/repositories/m2snapshots</url>
    </snapshotRepository>
  </distributionManagement>
</project>
{code}

{code:xml|title=settings.xml}
<settings xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/settings/1.0.0"
          xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
          xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/SETTINGS/1.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/settings-1.0.0.xsd">
  <interactiveMode>false</interactiveMode>
  <servers>
    <server>
      <id>nexus.objectledge.org</id>
      <username>bamboo</username>
      <password>***********</password>
    </server>
  </servers>
  <profiles>
    <profile>
      <id>bamboo</id>
      <activation>
         <activeByDefault>true</activeByDefault>
      </activation>
      <repositories>
        <repository>
          <snapshots>
            <enabled>true</enabled>
          </snapshots>
          <id>objectledge.snapshots</id>
          <name>ObjectLedge snapshots repository</name>
          <url>http://objectledge.org/nexus/content/repositories/m2snapshots</url>
        </repository>
      </repositories>
      <pluginRepositories>
        <pluginRepository>
          <snapshots>
            <enabled>true</enabled>
          </snapshots>
          <id>objectledge.snapshots</id>
          <name>ObjectLedge snapshots repository</name>
          <url>http://objectledge.org/nexus/content/repositories/m2snapshots</url>
        </pluginRepository>
      </pluginRepositories>
    </profile>
  </profiles>
</settings>
{code}

As you see I am using Nexus repository manager. SNAPSHOT artifacts built by bamboo are deployed to a dedicated repository. Both Nexus and Bamboo have artifact retention policies, but Maven2 has not. Whatever goes into the local repository, stays there. In order to avoid SNAPSHOT artifact buildup, I have a Bamboo plan running on fixed schedule that removes SNAPSHOTs from bamboo users local repository. Because of this, in order to build ledge-components module (and others), the parent POM needs to be resolved from remote repository. There's a catch - remote repository location is defined in the parent POM itself. That's why bamboo user needs the to have the repository defined in it's default Maven profile in order to bootstrap the build after the local repository has been purged.

This setup works the ordinary Bamboo builds, but Maven Dependency Processor fails resolve the parent project as indicated by error message above. 

I also did another test an executed {{sudo -u bamboo mvn dependency:list}} from the build-dir, which I imagine is quite similar to whatever the dependency processor is doing, and it worked without problems.

Too bad I cannot set maven options for the decadency processor task, a -X could shed some light on the issue.
fields.summary: Automatic Maven dependency processor fails to resolve parent project

fields.description:
It would be good if a build would fail if the artifact copier/publisher fails to find any artifacts using its search expression.
Some people might not want this so it would be good to configure this (on a per build plan/job basis - or a bamboo wide setting ??)

Situation:
We sometimes have the case where a build passes but there are no artifacts uploaded.
If there are builds dependant on this, then they go ahead and launch but they fail because any artifacts they need from the dependant build are not available.
Also some builds only pick up artifacts from the "latest successful" build so these are also affected.
fields.summary: Add configuration option for build fail if no artifacts are found.
Ensure that classpath.zip created after classpath scan is created in bamboo-home

fields.description:
For issue-driven-deployment we need the ability for a build to decide it's not needed and abort itself. If a plan receives a request to build along with a JIRA issue key and determines that there have been no source changes (it may be a dupe), then it should abort and not run dependent builds.

Currently the only task results are ERROR, FAILED & SUCCESS, which don't really work for us. (There will be genuine failure when merges fail etc, we do want alerts for these failures, but not when we abort.)

There are pre-conditions, however the problem with these are:
* They prevent the build for running so that there's no build. This would work for us, but it less than ideal.
* They do not receive the build parameters so can't actually determine whether the build should be run anyway.
fields.summary: Ability for a plan to choose to not run

fields.description:
All product admin screens are supposed to automatically require any resource with context "atl.admin". From what I tell in the Bamboo source, this feature is missing, even though it should be supported as of [PLUG 2.5|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/PLUGINFRAMEWORK/Plugin+Framework+2.5+Release+Notes#PluginFramework2.5ReleaseNotes-WebResourceContexts].

This is blocking a [UPM feature|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/UPM-1121] from working [in Bamboo|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/UPM-1143].
fields.summary: Bamboo admin screens do not require resources with context 'atl.admin'

fields.description:
Currently, if Bamboo is integrated with LDAP, and users were deleted in the external user repository, the dashboard will default to showing the name of the currently logged in user as the person who triggered a build, even if he wasn't the user who triggered it (a deleted user triggered it).

This "use of the current user" happens in the following situations:

1. The user who actually triggered the build has been deleted from LDAP
2. The user who actually triggered the build has had their permissions/groups in LDAP changed to no longer have the ability to trigger builds
3. The row for this build is missing in the 'BUILDRESULTSUMMARY_LABEL' table

Even if the user disappears (removed in LDAP or has his permissions changes in LDAP), it would be good to keep his name is the build history.

If there is no row in the 'BUILDRESULTSUMMARY_LABEL' table relating to this build, the name 'Unknown', or something similar in effect, should be displayed instead of the currently logged in user.
fields.summary: Continue displaying the original Username for who triggered the build even if the user is deleted

fields.description:
Currently if the build is running, all its Jobs will run using the same code revision.

However, if one of the first Jobs/Stages change the code repository (new commit) and we would like next Stage to use these changes (have them checked-out from the new revision), it is not possible, because all Jobs will use the same revision that was initially detected by the Plan.

It would be interesting to allow the Plan to continue interacting with the repository and detecting new revisions as the build runs.

A check box in the plan would be enough to enable/disable a detection of new revisions.
fields.summary: For the Perforce Source Repository add ability to only change directory to the Perforce workspace directory and skip sync (i.e. skip checkout/update)

fields.description:
from Jaie:

This milestone includes the update to the 2.0.0 selenium release (They released 2.1 today so that will becoming shortly).
There are few things to note. With 2.0.0 selenium there were some changes in the API.

- WebElement#getValue() were removed and it's suggested that you use WebElement#getAttribute('value')
- WebElement#setSelected() and WebElement#toggle() were removed and it's suggested that you use WebElement#click() instead. You can use WebElement#isSelected() to test to see if the element is already selected first.

- They removed the RenderedWebElement class altogether and moved the methods to WebElement. So previously if you wanted to see if an element was displayed you would do this:

WebElement el = driver.findElement(By.id("someId");
if ( ((RenderedWebElement) el).isDisplayed()) { ....

Now you can just use isDisplayed() directly on the WebElement no need to cast.

- The new Actions API is pretty solid now which means it's even easier to do Mouse and Keyboard events. eg.
Action action = new Action(driver);
action.moveToElement(WebElement el).perform(); // This should fire a hover() event if there is one.

Currently the hovering on elements works for all OS's if there is a javascript hover on the element, but for css pseudo class :hover it only works in windows and unix atm. They are working on getting native events working on Mac.

The actions class is composable so you can do things like:

Action action = new Action(driver);
action.click(WebElement el).sendKeys("abc").keyDown(Keys.ARROW_DOWN).keyUp(Keys.ARROW_DOWN).keyDown(Keys.ENTER).keyUp(Keys.ENTER).perform();

This means I'm slowly going to start deprecating some of the helper classes that we added for doing mouse events etc which will come through in either the 2.1 release or 2.2.

Can you let me know if you are still using any of the page objects from the framework (refapp-pageobject, confluence, jira etc) as I plan on removing them in either this release or the next.
fields.summary: Upgrade to atlassian-selenium 2.1-m4
